#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Drive an Air Bag Equipped Car
#Text=Beginning in the 1980s , vehicle manufacturers started installing air bags in vehicle steering wheels .

#Text=By 1998 , passenger vehicles were required to be equipped with dual air bags , while in 2001 , the National Highway Transportation Safety Administration ( NHTSA ) required that all new light trucks have dual air bags , one for the driver and one installed in the dashboard for the passenger .
#Text=Air bags are also located in the vehicle 's frame just above each door .
#Text=The force of an accidental collision trips an Airbag sensor , which activates a sodium azide fuse .
#Text=As the fuse is activated , it triggers the Airbag to deploy at a speed of 200 kilometers per hour ( 124 miles per hour ) .
#Text=Air bags deploy quickly , increasing the risk of injury or potential death if the driver is positioned too closely to the steering wheel .
#Text=Because of this , drivers need to learn how to drive an air-bag equipped car .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Understand how an Airbag works during a collision .
#Text=The letters " S.R.S. " stand for " supplementary restraint system , " which means the Airbag is intended to be used along with your car 's seat belts .

column1: #Text=Your seat belts are the primary restraint system protecting you in an accident .
#Text=The seat belts in your car help keep you positioned safely so that , if you are involved in a collision , the Airbag wo n't injure you when it deploys .
#Text=During a collision , a sensor in the vehicle signals the Airbag to ignite a fuse .
#Text=This fuse explodes and produces nitrogen gas .
#Text=The airbag deploys 50 milliseconds after a collision severe enough to warrant Airbag protection .
#Text=Position yourself and your children safely in your car .
#Text=The air bags in your car inflate very quickly .
#Text=You or your children could be seriously injured or killed if you 're sitting too close to an Airbag. .
#Text=Push the driver 's seat back far enough so that , if the Airbag deploys , you are n't injured by the force of deployment .
#Text=You should have at least 10 inches ( 25.4 cm ) of space between you and the airbag if it deploys .
#Text=Ask passengers to push the front passenger seat back far enough so they wo n't be injured by the airbags deployment during a collision .
#Text=Place a rear-facing infant car seat in the center rear set so the baby in the car seat is at a distance from the Airbag and the force of a potential collision .
#Text=Depending on the laws in your state , children may be required to ride in the back seat until they reach a certain age or height .
#Text=Because of their small size , a deploying Airbag can potentially kill a child .
#Text=Learn how to handle an air-bag equipped steering wheel .
#Text=Put your hands on the steering wheel in the 3 o'clock and 9 o'clock positions so you protect yourself from broken bones if the Airbag deploys .
#Text=Tow your car to a repair shop once it has been in a collision strong enough to cause Airbag deployment .
#Text=If your air bags have unexpectedly deployed , pull your car to the side of the road as soon as you safely can .
#Text=Schedule maintenance for your car as soon as you can if you get a recall notice regarding faulty air bags .
#Text=Tips
#Text=Air bags may not deploy for every type of collision .
#Text=Factors such as what you collide with and the angle of collision influence whether the Airbag will deploy .
#Text=There is no way to avoid an unexpected deployment unless you know your car has been recalled due to of faulty air bags .
#Text=You cannot safely test air bags to see if they are faulty .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=Do not drive your car once the air bags have deployed .
#Text=Do not tamper with the air bags or Airbag covers .
#Text=Do not attempt to disable the air bags in your car .
#Text=Federal law prohibits the disabling of air bags .
